The Forbidden City..passage: The Forbidden City is a palace complex in central Beijing, China. The former Chinese imperial palace from the Ming dynasty to the end of the Qing dynasty (the years 1420 to 1912), it now houses the Palace Museum. The Forbidden City served as the home of emperors and their households as well as the ceremonial and political center of Chinese government for almost 500 years. Constructed from 1406 to 1420, the complex consists of 980 buildings and covers 72 hectares (over 180 acres). The palace complex exemplifies traditional Chinese palatial architecture and has influenced cultural and architectural developments in East Asia and elsewhere. The Forbidden City was declared a World Heritage Site in 1987, and is listed by UNESCO as the largest collection of preserved ancient wooden structures in the world.

Terracotta Army..passage: The Terracotta Army is a collection of terracotta sculptures depicting the armies of Qin Shi Huang, the first Emperor of China. It is a form of funerary art buried with the emperor in 210–209 BCE with the purpose of protecting the emperor in his afterlife. The figures, dating from approximately the late third century BCE, were discovered in 1974 by local farmers in Lintong District, Xi'an, Shaanxi province. The figures vary in height according to their roles, with the tallest being the generals. The figures include warriors, chariots and horses. Estimates from 2007 were that the three pits containing the Terracotta Army held more than 8,000 soldiers, 130 chariots with 520 horses, and 150 cavalry horses, the majority of which remained buried in the pits near Qin Shi Huang's mausoleum. Other terracotta non-military figures were also found in other pits and they include officials, acrobats, strongmen, and musicians.

Maurya Empire..passage: The Maurya Empire was a geographically extensive Iron Age historical power based in Magadha and founded by Chandragupta Maurya which dominated the Indian subcontinent between 322 and 185 BCE. Comprising the majority of South Asia, the Maurya Empire was centralized by the conquest of the Indo-Gangetic Plain, and its capital city was located at Pataliputra (modern Patna). The empire was the largest political entity to have existed in the Indian subcontinent, spanning over 5 million square kilometres at its zenith under Ashoka. It declined for about 50 years after Ashoka's rule ended, and it dissolved in 185 BCE with the foundation of the Shunga dynasty in Magadha. Under Chandragupta and his successors, internal and external trade, agriculture, and economic activities all thrived and expanded across India thanks to the creation of a single and efficient system of finance, administration, and security. After the Kalinga War, the Empire experienced nearly half a century of peace and security under Ashoka. Mauryan India also enjoyed an era of social harmony, religious transformation, and expansion of the sciences and of knowledge. Chandragupta Maurya's embrace of Jainism increased social and religious renewal and reform across his society, while Ashoka's embrace of Buddhism has been said to have been the foundation of the reign of social and political peace and non-violence across all of India.

qae_pairs.explanation: The ruler of the Maurya Empire during its zenith was Ashoka, as stated in the passage.

Mughal Empire..passage: The Mughal Empire was an empire in the Indian subcontinent, founded in 1526. It was ruled by the Mughal dynasty, which originated in Turkestan. The empire was notable for its cultural achievements, including the development of Mughal architecture, a blend of Islamic, Persian, and Indian styles. The Mughals were also patrons of the arts, and their court was home to many poets, musicians, and artists. The empire was known for its military prowess, and its armies were among the most powerful in the world at the time. The Mughals were also known for their religious tolerance, and they allowed Hindus, Muslims, and other religious groups to practice their faiths freely. The empire declined in the 18th century, and was eventually dissolved by the British in the mid-19th century. Despite its decline, the Mughal Empire remains an important part of Indian history and culture, and its legacy can still be seen in the architecture, art, and literature of the region.

Himalayan mountains..passage: The Himalayas, or Himalaya, is a mountain range in Asia separating the plains of the Indian subcontinent from the Tibetan Plateau. The range has some of the planet's highest peaks, including the highest, Mount Everest. The Himalayas include over fifty mountains exceeding 7,200 m (23,600 ft) in elevation, including ten of the fourteen 8,000-metre peaks. By contrast, the highest peak outside Asia (Aconcagua, in the Andes) is 6,961 m (22,838 ft) tall. The Himalayas have profoundly shaped the cultures of South Asia. Many Himalayan peaks are sacred in both Hinduism and Buddhism. In Hinduism, Mount Kailash is regarded as the abode of Lord Shiva. The Himalayas are also important to the world of mountaineering, with many peaks being climbed for the first time in the early 20th century.

Goa..passage: Goa is a state located in the western region of India, bounded by the Arabian Sea to the west, Maharashtra to the north, and Karnataka to the east and south. It is India's smallest state by area and the fourth-smallest by population. Goa is known for its beaches, nightlife, and Portuguese colonial architecture. The state was a Portuguese colony from the 16th century until 1961, when it was annexed by India. Goa is divided into two districts, North Goa and South Goa, and its capital is Panaji. The state's official language is Konkani, but English and Hindi are also widely spoken. Goa is a popular tourist destination, attracting millions of visitors each year. Its beaches, such as Baga and Calangute, are known for their white sand and clear waters. The state is also home to several historic churches and temples, including the Basilica of Bom Jesus and the Shri Mangueshi Temple. Goa is also famous for its cuisine, which blends Indian and Portuguese influences. Some popular dishes include vindaloo, sorpotel, and fish curry.

Tasmania..passage: Tasmania is an island state of Australia located south of the mainland. It is the smallest state in Australia, but it is also one of the most beautiful and unique. Tasmania is known for its rugged wilderness areas, stunning beaches, and rich history. The island was first inhabited by the indigenous Tasmanian Aboriginal people, who lived there for thousands of years before the arrival of European explorers in the 17th century. Today, Tasmania is home to a diverse population of people from all over the world, and it is a popular destination for tourists who come to explore its natural beauty and learn about its fascinating history. Some of the most popular attractions in Tasmania include the Cradle Mountain-Lake St. Clair National Park, the Tasmanian Devil Conservation Park, and the historic Port Arthur penal settlement. Tasmania is also known for its delicious food and wine, with many local producers offering fresh seafood, cheese, and wine that are famous throughout Australia and beyond. Overall, Tasmania is a unique and beautiful part of Australia that is well worth a visit for anyone who loves nature, history, and good food.

The Commonwealth of Australia..passage: The Commonwealth of Australia is a sovereign country comprising the mainland of the Australian continent, the island of Tasmania, and numerous smaller islands. It is the world's sixth-largest country by total area. The neighbouring countries are Papua New Guinea, Indonesia, and East Timor to the north; the Solomon Islands and Vanuatu to the north-east; and New Zealand to the south-east. Australia's capital is Canberra, and its largest city is Sydney. For about 60,000 years before the first British settlement in the late 18th century, Australia was inhabited by indigenous Australians, who spoke languages grouped into roughly 250 language groups. After the European discovery of the continent by Dutch explorers in 1606, Australia's eastern half was claimed by Great Britain in 1770 and initially settled through penal transportation to the colony of New South Wales from 26 January 1788. The population grew steadily in subsequent decades, and by the 1850s most of the continent had been explored and an additional five self-governing crown colonies established. On 1 January 1901, the six colonies federated, forming the Commonwealth of Australia. Australia has since maintained a stable liberal democratic political system that functions as a federal parliamentary constitutional monarchy, comprising six states and ten territories.

ANZUS..passage: The Australia, New Zealand, United States Security Treaty (ANZUS or ANZUS Treaty) is a collective defense agreement between Australia, New Zealand, and the United States that was signed in 1951. The treaty provides for mutual defense assistance in the event of an attack on any of the three countries. It also includes provisions for consultation and cooperation on matters of common interest, such as regional security and economic development. The ANZUS Treaty has been an important component of the security architecture of the Asia-Pacific region for over six decades, and has played a key role in maintaining peace and stability in the region. Despite its importance, the treaty has faced challenges in recent years, including tensions between the United States and some of its allies, and concerns about the rise of China and its impact on regional security. Nevertheless, the ANZUS Treaty remains a vital tool for promoting security and stability in the Asia-Pacific region, and its continued relevance will be critical in the years to come.

G20..passage: The G20 (Group of Twenty) is an international forum for the governments and central bank governors from 19 countries and the European Union (EU). It was established in 1999 with the aim of promoting international financial stability and economic growth. The G20 countries represent around 80% of the world's gross domestic product (GDP) and two-thirds of the world's population. The members of the G20 are Argentina, Australia, Brazil, Canada, China, France, Germany, India, Indonesia, Italy, Japan, Mexico, Russia, Saudi Arabia, South Africa, South Korea, Turkey, the United Kingdom, and the United States. The European Union is also a member, represented by the European Council and the European Central Bank. The G20 holds annual summits where leaders discuss a range of global economic issues, including trade, investment, financial regulation, and climate change. The G20 has been criticized for being too exclusive and not representative of the wider international community, as well as for its lack of concrete action on some of the issues it discusses. However, it remains an important forum for global economic cooperation and coordination.

Middle Stone Age..passage: The Middle Stone Age (MSA) was a period of African prehistory between the Early Stone Age and the Later Stone Age. It is generally considered to have begun around 280,000 years ago and ended around 50,000–25,000 years ago. The MSA is characterized by the development of new stone tool technologies, including the Levallois technique, which allowed for the production of more complex and versatile tools. The MSA also saw the emergence of Homo sapiens, the species to which modern humans belong. The MSA is an important period in human evolution, as it marks the transition from archaic to modern humans and the development of complex social and cultural behaviors. The MSA is also significant for the evidence it provides of early human migration and the development of human societies in Africa.

African Union..passage: The African Union (AU) is a continental union consisting of 55 member states located on the continent of Africa. The AU was established on 26 May 2001 in Addis Ababa and launched on 9 July 2002 in South Africa to replace the Organisation of African Unity (OAU). The main objectives of the AU are to promote political and economic integration among its member states, and to advance the interests of Africa as a whole. The AU is headquartered in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia, and has a number of subsidiary bodies, including the Pan-African Parliament, the African Court of Justice and Human Rights, and the African Union Commission. The AU has been instrumental in promoting peace and security on the continent, and has played a key role in resolving conflicts in countries such as Sudan, Somalia, and the Democratic Republic of Congo. The AU has also been active in promoting economic development and regional integration, and has launched a number of initiatives aimed at boosting trade and investment among its member states. Despite these achievements, the AU faces a number of challenges, including the ongoing conflict in South Sudan, the threat of terrorism in the Sahel region, and the need to address issues such as poverty, inequality, and corruption.

Leo Tolstoy..passage: Leo Tolstoy was a Russian writer who is regarded as one of the greatest authors of all time. He was born in 1828 in Yasnaya Polyana, a small village in central Russia. Tolstoy came from a wealthy and aristocratic family and was educated at home by French and German tutors. He later attended the University of Kazan but dropped out before completing his degree. Tolstoy's literary career began in the 1850s with the publication of his first novel, "Childhood." He went on to write several other novels, including "War and Peace" and "Anna Karenina," which are considered to be his masterpieces. Tolstoy's writing is known for its realism, psychological depth, and social commentary. He was particularly interested in exploring the lives of ordinary people and the social and political issues of his time. In addition to his writing, Tolstoy was also a social and political activist. He was deeply influenced by his Christian faith and became a pacifist and anarchist later in life. He advocated for nonviolent resistance and rejected the authority of the state and the church. Tolstoy's political views and his criticism of the Russian government and the Orthodox Church led to his excommunication in 1901. Tolstoy died in 1910 at the age of 82. His legacy as a writer and thinker continues to influence literature and social movements around the world.

Ural Mountains..passage: The Ural Mountains, also known as the Urals, are a mountain range that runs approximately from north to south through western Russia, from the coast of the Arctic Ocean to the Ural River and northwestern Kazakhstan. The range forms part of the conventional boundary between the continents of Europe and Asia. Vaygach Island and the islands of Novaya Zemlya form a further continuation of the chain to the north into the Arctic Ocean. The mountains significantly overlap with the Ural economic region. They have rich resources, including metal ores, coal, precious and semi-precious stones. Since the 18th century the mountains have contributed significantly to the mineral sector of the Russian economy. The eastern side of the Ural Mountains is a series of plateaus and depressions, including the Vogulsky Mountains and the Tagilskaya Plain. The western side is generally lower, with extensive plains and lowlands, including the Kama and Chusovaya River basins. The highest peak in the range is Mount Narodnaya, which reaches a height of 1,894 meters (6,214 ft). The Ural Mountains have a diverse climate, with the western side being more humid and the eastern side being more arid. The range is also home to a variety of flora and fauna, including several endangered species such as the Siberian tiger and the snow leopard. The Ural Mountains have played an important role in Russian history, serving as a natural barrier between Europe and Asia and as a source of valuable resources. They have also been the site of several significant events, including the Battle of the Urals during World War II and the meteor explosion over Chelyabinsk in 2013. Today, the mountains are a popular destination for outdoor enthusiasts, offering opportunities for hiking, skiing, and other activities.

Iguazu Falls..passage: Iguazu Falls, also known as Iguassu Falls or Iguaçu Falls, are a series of waterfalls located on the Iguazu River on the border of the Argentine province of Misiones and the Brazilian state of Paraná. The falls are one of the largest waterfalls in the world and are considered one of the Seven Natural Wonders of the World. The total width of the falls is 2.7 kilometers (1.7 miles) and the height varies between 60 meters (197 feet) and 82 meters (269 feet). The most famous of the falls is the Devil's Throat, a U-shaped chasm that is 82 meters (269 feet) high, 150 meters (492 feet) wide, and 700 meters (2,297 feet) long. The falls are surrounded by the Iguazu National Park, which is a UNESCO World Heritage Site. The park is home to a variety of wildlife, including jaguars, ocelots, and toucans. The falls are a popular tourist destination and attract millions of visitors each year.

Andorra..passage: Andorra, officially the Principality of Andorra, is a sovereign landlocked microstate on the Iberian Peninsula, in the eastern Pyrenees, bordered by France to the north and Spain to the south. Commonwealth of Nations..passage: The Commonwealth of Nations, also known simply as the Commonwealth, is a political association of 54 member states, nearly all of which are former territories of the British Empire. The chief institutions of the organisation are the Commonwealth Secretariat, which focuses on intergovernmental aspects, and the Commonwealth Foundation, which focuses on non-governmental relations between member states. The Commonwealth dates back to the mid-20th century with the decolonisation of the British Empire through increased self-governance of its territories. It was formally constituted by the London Declaration in 1949, which established the member states as "free and equal". The symbol of this free association is Queen Elizabeth II who is the Head of the Commonwealth. The Queen is also the monarch of 16 members of the Commonwealth, known as Commonwealth realms. The Commonwealth is a forum for political dialogue between member states, but it does not have any formal powers or obligations. It is also a platform for cultural exchange and cooperation, and its members are committed to promoting democracy, human rights, and economic development. The Commonwealth has been criticised for its lack of action on issues such as climate change and human rights abuses in member states, but it remains an important international organisation with a diverse membership and a shared history.

Israel..passage: Israel, officially known as the State of Israel, is a country located in the Middle East, bordered by Lebanon to the north, Syria to the northeast, Jordan to the east, Egypt to the southwest, and the Mediterranean Sea to the west. The history of Israel dates back to biblical times, with the Jewish people claiming a connection to the land for over 3,000 years. In 1947, the United Nations voted to partition Palestine into two states, one Jewish and one Arab. The following year, Israel declared its independence, leading to a war with neighboring Arab countries. Israel is known for its diverse culture, including its cuisine, music, and art. It is also home to many historical and religious sites, such as the Western Wall, the Dome of the Rock, and the Church of the Holy Sepulchre. The country is a leader in technology and innovation, with a thriving startup scene and a strong focus on research and development. Despite its many achievements, Israel faces ongoing challenges, including tensions with its neighbors, political divisions, and ongoing conflict with the Palestinians. However, the country remains a vibrant and dynamic society, with a rich history and a promising future.

The Sahara Desert..passage: The Sahara Desert is the largest hot desert in the world, covering approximately 3.6 million square miles in North Africa. It stretches from the Atlantic Ocean in the west to the Red Sea in the east, and from the Mediterranean Sea in the north to the Sahel region in the south. The Sahara is known for its extreme temperatures, with daytime temperatures often exceeding 120°F and nighttime temperatures dropping below freezing. The desert is also known for its vast sand dunes, rocky plateaus, and occasional oasis. Despite its harsh conditions, the Sahara has been inhabited by humans for thousands of years, with evidence of ancient civilizations and trade routes still visible today. The desert is home to a variety of unique flora and fauna, including the Saharan cheetah, dromedary camels, and date palms. However, the Sahara is also facing environmental challenges, including desertification and the encroachment of human activity.

Despite its long and storied history, Alexandria remains a dynamic and forward-looking city, with a bright future ahead.

The OIC has permanent delegations to the United Nations and the European Union. The official languages of the OIC are Arabic, English, and French. The OIC is composed of 57 member states, including 56 sovereign states and the State of Palestine. Some members, especially in West Africa and South America, are – though with large Muslim populations – not necessarily Muslim majority countries. The collective population of OIC member states is over 1.8 billion as of 2015. Hosni Mubarak..passage: Hosni Mubarak was an Egyptian military and political leader who served as the fourth President of Egypt from 1981 to 2011. He was born in Kafr-El-Meselha, a small village in the Nile Delta, in 1928. Mubarak joined the Egyptian Air Force in 1950 and rose through the ranks to become its commander in 1972. He played a key role in the Yom Kippur War against Israel in 1973, which helped to restore Egypt's pride after the defeat in the Six-Day War of 1967. Mubarak became Vice President of Egypt in 1975 and succeeded Anwar Sadat as President after his assassination in 1981. During his presidency, Mubarak maintained Egypt's peace treaty with Israel, which was signed in 1979, and pursued a policy of economic liberalization and privatization. However, his regime was criticized for its human rights abuses, corruption, and lack of political freedom. In 2011, a popular uprising against Mubarak's rule erupted in Egypt, fueled by frustration with his authoritarianism, economic inequality, and corruption. After 18 days of protests, Mubarak resigned on February 11, 2011, and handed power to the military. He was subsequently put on trial for corruption and complicity in the killing of protesters during the uprising. In 2012, he was sentenced to life in prison, but the verdict was overturned on appeal. Mubarak was released from prison in 2017 and died in February 2020 at the age of 91.

Abdel Fattah el-Sisi..passage: Abdel Fattah el-Sisi is an Egyptian politician who has been serving as the President of Egypt since 2014. He was born on November 19, 1954, in Cairo, Egypt. El-Sisi graduated from the Egyptian Military Academy in 1977 and went on to receive further military training in the United States and the United Kingdom. He served in various positions in the Egyptian Armed Forces, including as the Director of Military Intelligence and the Minister of Defense. El-Sisi rose to prominence during the 2011 Egyptian revolution, which led to the ousting of President Hosni Mubarak. He was appointed as the head of the Supreme Council of the Armed Forces, which governed Egypt during the transitional period. In 2012, he was appointed as the Minister of Defense by President Mohamed Morsi. In 2013, el-Sisi led a military coup that ousted Morsi from power. He then became the de facto leader of Egypt and was later elected as the President in 2014. El-Sisi's presidency has been marked by a crackdown on political dissent and human rights abuses. He has been accused of suppressing opposition voices, jailing journalists and activists, and using excessive force against protesters. Despite criticism from human rights organizations, el-Sisi remains popular among many Egyptians who see him as a strong leader who can restore stability to the country. He has implemented economic reforms and launched large-scale infrastructure projects, including the construction of a new administrative capital city. El-Sisi has also played a key role in regional politics, particularly in the ongoing conflict in Libya. El-Sisi's presidency has been controversial, with some accusing him of authoritarianism and others praising him for his efforts to modernize Egypt. His legacy remains a subject of debate, and his future as the leader of Egypt is uncertain.

Persian Empire..passage: The Persian Empire, also known as the Achaemenid Empire, was a vast empire that existed from 550 BCE to 330 BCE. It was founded by Cyrus the Great, who united several tribes in the region and established a powerful kingdom. The empire was known for its military might, administrative efficiency, and cultural achievements. It spanned three continents, including parts of Asia, Europe, and Africa, and was the largest empire in the world at the time. Under the Persian Empire, many advancements were made in various fields, including architecture, art, literature, and science. The empire was also known for its religious tolerance, as it allowed its subjects to practice their own religions and even supported the construction of temples and other religious structures. The Persian Empire was ruled by a series of powerful kings, including Cyrus the Great, Darius the Great, and Xerxes I. These kings were known for their military conquests, as they expanded the empire's borders through a series of successful campaigns. The empire's military was highly organized and disciplined, and it was able to defeat many of its enemies through superior tactics and technology. Despite its many achievements, the Persian Empire eventually fell to the armies of Alexander the Great in 330 BCE. However, its legacy lived on, as many of its cultural and scientific achievements were adopted by subsequent empires and civilizations. Today, the Persian Empire is remembered as one of the greatest empires in history, and its influence can still be seen in many aspects of modern culture.

Centuries..passage: Centuries are units of time that are equal to 100 years. They are commonly used to measure the duration of historical events, cultural movements, and other long-term phenomena. Nevertheless, they remain a valuable way to organize and understand the complex events and trends that shape human history.

OPEC..passage: The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC) is a cartel of 14 countries that produce and export oil. OPEC was founded in 1960 with the goal of coordinating and unifying the petroleum policies of its member countries, in order to secure fair and stable prices for petroleum producers and a regular supply for consumers. OPEC's members collectively control around 44% of global oil production and 73% of the "proven" oil reserves. The organization is headquartered in Vienna, Austria, and its decisions are made by the OPEC Conference, which meets twice a year.
